text: Antibiotic exposure + ≥3 unformed stools/day → test C. difficile toxins; treat confirmed cases with fidaxomicin or vancomycin.
Prior cesarean + abdominal pain + fetal distress + loss of station suggests uterine rupture; immediate surgical exploration is indicated.
Constrictive pericarditis: Kussmaul sign, pericardial knock, respiratory ventricular interdependence; limited response to diuretics.
Reactive perforating collagenosis: umbilicated keratotic papules with transepidermal elimination; often pruritic on extensor surfaces.
Acetylcholine-receptor antibody positivity with fatigable ocular or bulbar weakness supports myasthenia gravis; symptoms worsen with exertion and improve with rest.
Natalizumab exposure is associated with risk of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy; MRI shows multifocal non-enhancing demyelinating lesions in white matter.
Jugular venous distention with Kussmaul sign, pericardial knock, and ventricular interdependence on imaging favor constrictive pericarditis over restrictive cardiomyopathy.
Hemolytic anemia presents with elevated LDH, indirect bilirubin, reticulocytosis, and low haptoglobin; peripheral smear may show spherocytes or schistocytes depending on cause.
Situational syncope triggered during or after urination in otherwise healthy individuals suggests a vasovagal mechanism with normal ECG findings.
Long-term hydroquinone use can cause blue-black or gray-brown facial hyperpigmentation, often mottled, sparing mucosa; biopsy shows dermal yellow-brown pigment (ochronosis).
Shiny yellow-brown atrophic plaques with telangiectasias on anterior shins, often in diabetes; borders elevated with central atrophy; may ulcerate.
Tender, erythematous subcutaneous nodules on anterior shins; usually no ulceration; often post-streptococcal, sarcoidosis, IBD, or drugs.
Recurrent painful nodules, abscesses, and sinus tracts in intertriginous areas (axilla, groin); double-comedones; chronic scarring.
Umbilicated, dome-shaped papules; central dell with keratin plug; common in children, immunosuppressed adults, or after skin trauma.
Intensely pruritic papules worse at night; burrows in finger webs, wrists, waistline; close contacts often affected.
Hypo- or hyper-pigmented finely scaling macules on trunk; KOH shows ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ (hyphae + spores).
Scalp scaling with patchy alopecia and broken hairs; posterior cervical lymphadenopathy in children; treat with oral antifungal.
Violaceous psoriasiform plaques of nose, ears, and acral sites; often paraneoplastic (upper aerodigestive SCC).
Rapidly enlarging, firm, mobile breast mass with leaf-like architecture on histology; may mimic fibroadenoma but grows quickly; wide local excision needed.
Well-circumscribed, mobile, rubbery breast mass in young women; slow growth; ultrasound shows oval, homogeneous, parallel mass.
Rapidly growing crateriform nodule with central keratin plug on sun-exposed skin; considered a variant of squamous cell carcinoma.
Pearly papule with telangiectasias and rolled borders; ulceration (‘rodent ulcer’) in advanced lesions; sun-exposed areas.
Symmetric pruritic erythematous maculopapular rash starting on trunk 1–2 weeks after new medication; spares mucosa.
Irregular, broken, net-like violaceous patches suggest livedo racemosa; consider vasculopathy/antiphospholipid syndrome.
Palpable purpura on dependent areas; biopsy with neutrophilic small-vessel vasculitis and leukocytoclasia; can be drug- or infection-related.
Progressive myopia/astigmatism with scissoring reflex, Munson sign (V-shaped lid on downgaze), and Vogt striae; conical cornea on topography.
Pterygium is a triangular fibrovascular growth crossing the limbus toward cornea; pinguecula is a yellow conjunctival deposit that does not cross the limbus.
Entropion is inward eyelid turning causing lash-corneal irritation; ectropion is outward turning with exposure symptoms and tearing.
Painful red eye with photophobia, consensual pain, and cells/flare on slit lamp; small irregular pupil from posterior synechiae.
Severe, boring eye pain worse with eye movement; diffuse or nodular violaceous scleral injection; may be associated with systemic autoimmune disease.
Sudden painless monocular vision loss; fundus shows pale retina with a cherry-red spot at the fovea; afferent pupillary defect present.
Terminal hematuria and urinary frequency in endemic exposure; calcified bladder wall on imaging; risk of squamous cell carcinoma of bladder.
Hypopigmented or erythematous anesthetic patches with thickened peripheral nerves; loss of temperature/pain sensation within lesions.
Chronic painless ulcer with raised indurated borders at sandfly-exposed sites; travel/residency in endemic regions.
Delayed passage of meconium (>48 hours), abdominal distension, explosive stool after rectal exam; contrast enema shows transition zone; rectal biopsy is diagnostic.
≥3 unformed stools/day after antibiotic exposure: test for C. difficile toxins; treat confirmed infection with fidaxomicin or vancomycin.
Laboring patient with prior uterine surgery who develops sudden abdominal pain, fetal distress, and loss of fetal station—suspect uterine rupture and proceed to emergent laparotomy.
Acute interstitial nephritis: fever, rash, eosinophilia, and rising creatinine after new drug (e.g., beta-lactam, PPI, NSAID); urine with WBCs/WBC casts; eosinophiluria variably present.
Long-term hemodialysis predisposes to beta-2 microglobulin amyloidosis; presents with shoulder/wrist pain, carpal tunnel, and bone cysts; radiographs may show lytic lesions near joints.
ANCA-associated vasculitis causes pulmonary-renal syndrome with hematuria, RBC casts, nodular/cavitating lung lesions; treat with steroids plus rituximab or cyclophosphamide.
Inflammatory back pain starts <40 years, improves with exercise, not rest; limited chest expansion and sacroiliitis on imaging; HLA-B27 frequent.
Coarsened facial features, enlarged hands/feet, widened spaced teeth, skin tags, and deep voice; screen with IGF-1, confirm with oral glucose GH suppression test.
Acute knee pain with inability to actively extend the knee or perform straight-leg raise; palpable suprapatellar gap; patella baja on imaging.
Fall on outstretched hand with snuffbox tenderness; initial radiographs may be normal; immobilize in thumb spica and repeat imaging.
Hemolytic anemia with acrocyanosis after Mycoplasma or EBV; positive cold agglutinin test; treat underlying infection and keep warm; rituximab for persistent cases.
Acute hemolysis after fava beans, sulfa drugs, nitrofurantoin, or dapsone; bite cells and Heinz bodies on smear; G6PD assay confirms (may be normal during crisis).
HFpEF shows impaired relaxation without pericardial knock or pronounced ventricular interdependence; constrictive pericarditis shows Kussmaul sign and discordant LV/RV pressures.
Painful swelling of submandibular or parotid gland worse with meals suggests obstructive sialolithiasis; ultrasound/CT may show stone; treat with hydration, sialogogues, massage.
Necrotic black eschars with erythematous halo in septic or neutropenic patients suggest ecthyma gangrenosum (Pseudomonas).
Painless papule at inoculation site that ulcerates; nodules spread proximally along lymphatics (‘sporotrichoid’ pattern); gardening/rose thorns exposure.
Pain with eye movement and acute monocular vision loss with decreased color vision; afferent pupillary defect; consider MS or MOG/NMOSD depending on context.
